contentrichtext.text: {{wikisource|United States Statutes at Large/Volume 1/5th Congress/2nd Session/Chapter 54|Naturalization Act of 1798}}The '''Naturalization Act''', passed by [[United States Congress|Congress]] on June 18, 1798 (1 Stat. 566), increased the amount of time necessary for immigrants to become [[naturalized]] [[citizen]]s in the [[United States]] from five to fourteen years. Although it was passed under the guise of protecting national security, most historians conclude it was really intended to decrease the number of voters who disagreed with the [[Federalist]] [[political party]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Watkins|first=William J., Jr.|title=Reclaiming the American Revolution|page=28|ISBN=0-230-60257-6}}</ref> At the time, most immigrants (namely [[Ireland|Irish]] and [[France|French]]) supported [[Thomas Jefferson]] and the [[Democratic-Republicans]], the political opponents of the Federalists. This act was repealed in 1802 by the [[Naturalization Law of 1802]]. A number of changes were made to the previous naturalization law: {|class='wikitable' !Act |[[Naturalization Act of 1790]] |[[Naturalization Act of 1795]] |Naturalization Act of 1798 |- !Notice time |no notice required |3 years |5 years |- !Residence period |2 years |5 years |14 years |} The "notice time" refers to how long immigrants had to wait after declaring their intent to become a citizen. The "residence period" refers to how long they had to live in the [[United States]] before they could become a citizen. The Naturalization Act is considered one of the [[Alien and Sedition Acts]] passed contemporaneously in 1798. Like the Naturalization Acts of 1790 and 1795, this act also restricted citizenship to "free white persons". Note the recognition of the distinction between ''native, citizen, denizen, or subject of any nation or state'' within the act. This act is the first to record immigration, maintain records of residence, and make certificates of residence for white immigrant aliens, for the purpose of establishing the date of arrival for subsequent qualification for naturalization. ==References== <references /> ==External links== * [[s:United States Statutes at Large/Volume 1/5th Congress/2nd Session/Chapter 54|Statutes at Large, 5th Congress, 2nd Session: Naturalization Act]] {{Immigration to the United States}} [[Category:1798 in law]] [[Category:United States federal immigration and nationality legislation]] [[Category:Presidency of John Adams]] [[Category:United States repealed legislation]]
